newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-HK Newspaper Headlines - Oct 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-HK Newspaper Headlines - Oct 17.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- SING TAO -- Chinese Vice-Premier Qian Qichen said during a newspaper interview Hong Kong people would be banned from commemorating the June 4, 1989 Beijing crackdown and from making "personal attacks" on Chinese leaders.
-- A total of 4,305 AIDS cases had been reported in China since 1985. The disease spread to 28 provinces and cities. Experts estimated the number of Chinese who had contracted it had reached 100,000.
-- MING PAO -- According to the latest Chinese property index, property prices in China were stable and the market outlook was positive.
-- APPLE DAILY -- After travelling for 30 hours, Chinese dissident Wang Xizhe finally arrived safely in San Francisco.
-- Macau activists planned to rent helicopters to land on the disputed Diaoyu (Senkaku) islands to dismantle a lighthouse built by Japanese right-wing groups.
-- Beijing-funded TA KUNG PAO -- Chinese Minister of Foreign Economic and Trade Cooperation Wu Yi said China would try to reform the Canton Fair and bring in services trade.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- Beijing invited foreign financial bodies, including Morgan Stanley, to give advice on how the Chinese government could support financial development in Hong Kong after the handover.
-- English-language SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- The Hong Kong and British governments came under fire in the Legislative Council for "mishandling" relations with China.
-- Three Chinese companies listed in Hong Kong and New York planned to issue Eurodollar convertible bonds worth a combined US$500 million late this year and early next year.
-- Foreign executives who spoke to Beijing officials this week said China was backing away from its longstanding promise to allow foreign banks to conduct yuan business soon.
-- English-language HONGKONG STANDARD -- Hong Kong Telecom might fight a government ruling that competitors should be allowed to offer international virtual private networking services.
-- Troubled CK Securities was seeking outside help to restructure its operations.
